tool.name: plot semivariogram
tool.description: Fits a model between two distance matrices and plots the result
tool.command:
plot_semivariogram.py -x $input_path_x -y $input_path_y -o plot_semivariogram_output #if str($binning): -b $binning #end if
#if $ignore_missing_samples: --ignore_missing_samples #end if
#if $x_max: --x_max=$x_max #end if
#if $x_min: --x_min=$x_min #end if
#if $y_max: --y_max=$y_max #end if
#if $y_min: --y_min=$y_min #end if
#if str($x_label): -X $x_label #end if
#if str($y_label): -Y $y_label #end if
#if str($fig_title): -t $fig_title #end if
#if str($dot_color): --dot_color=$dot_color #end if
#if str($dot_marker): --dot_marker=$dot_marker #end if
#if str($line_color): --line_color=$line_color #end if
#if $dot_alpha: --dot_alpha=$dot_alpha #end if
#if $line_alpha: --line_alpha=$line_alpha #end if
#if str($model) != 'None': -m $model #end if
#if $print_model: -p #end if ; compress_path.py -i plot_semivariogram_output -o $output_path

param.label: -x/--input_path_x: path to distance matrix to be displayed in the x axis
param.name: input_path_x

param.label: -y/--input_path_y: path to distance matrix to be displayed in the y axis
param.name: input_path_y

param.label: -b/--binning: binning ranges. Format: [increment,top_limit], when top_limit is -1=infinitum; you can specify several ranges using the same format, i.e. [2.5,10][50,-1] will set two bins, one from 0-10 using 2.5 size steps and from 10-inf using 50 size steps. Note that the binning is used to clean the plots (reduce number of points) but ignored to fit the model. [default: None]
param.name: binning

param.label: --ignore_missing_samples: This will overpass the error raised when the matrices have different sizes/samples
param.name: ignore_missing_samples

param.label: -X/--x_label: Label for the x axis [default: Distance Dissimilarity (m)]
param.name: x_label

param.label: -Y/--y_label: Label for the y axis [default: Community Dissimilarity]
param.name: y_label

param.label: --dot_color: dot color for plot, more info: http://matplotlib.sourceforge.net/api/pyplot_api.html [default: white]
param.name: dot_color

param.label: --dot_marker: dot color for plot, more info: http://matplotlib.sourceforge.net/api/pyplot_api.html [default: o]
param.name: dot_marker

param.label: --line_color: line color for plot, more info: http://matplotlib.sourceforge.net/api/pyplot_api.html [default: blue]
param.name: line_color

param.label: -m/--model: model to be fitted to the data. Valid choices are:nugget, exponential, gaussian, periodic, linear. [default: exponential]
param.name: model

param.label: -p/--print_model: Print in the title of the plot the function of the fit. [default: False]
param.name: print_model

tool.help: Fits a spatial autocorrelation model between two matrices and plots the result. This script will work with two distance matrices but will ignore the 0s at the diagonal and the values that go to N/A The resulting output file consists of a pdf image containing the plot between the two distances matrices and the fitted model
